B000A88EVE|5.0|I went into this film expecting something more like Walkabout, because that is all I had seen of Nicholas Roeg's work previously, and the thought of David Bowie being in it enticed me. Really, though, I had it backwards... It's David Bowie's creation with a little bit of Nicholas Roeg in it.<br /><br />The whole \\"human alien\\" thing is very much Bowie's schtick, and to a degree I found it hard not to imagine that this was Bowie's entire idea of himself. A sort of silent tragedy encompasses his character, expressed mostly in the scene with the eye-test where Bowie says very smally and pathetically \\"Oh... now I'll never get them out.\\" Bowie sees himself as an alien that just can't escape being human.<br /><br />On a broader sense than this one artist's idea, however, this is a fascinating science fiction film because it points out a side of human nature not often developed very well in other science fiction films. Instead of dissecting the alien, which is what everyone always expects humans will do, the humans do everything in their power to make him more human. Where not actually working towards constructing this \\"other\\" as a human, they try to own him, via capitalism or politics or, yes, even love.<br /><br />It's interesting then the space they put him in, with all of the various rooms like different human-empathetic places. On one hand, it's a self-reflective look at the \\"set\\" of the movie, showing that we are designing this alien to look human, but secondly a lot of it is surreally natural, as if to imply that even nature is forced to be human at our hands.<br /><br />--PolarisDiB
B00005JKL8|3.0|This was a rather annoying movie- one of those that I don't really enjoy, but manages to be just barely interesting enough to keep me watching it, even though I know how it will end. <br /> <br />Maybe the problem is that the film already seems dated- the music, the lightning fast camera shifts, even the setting in war-torn Bosnia- it just did not manage to retain its relevance in the same way that Black Hawk Down did. <br /> <br />It was strange to see Owen Wilson in a serious role because I'm used to him playing somewhat smarmy characters, but he carried it off quite well. B000E1ZBGS|4.0|WARNING:  Plot points exposed in the following review... <br /> <br />As a tremendous fan of the 1995 BBC miniseries I was curious as to how well the story would fare in a mere 127 minutes (versus the 300 minute miniseries behemoth).  Though seemingly rushed in places (there are plot points that could have done with more exposition - the character of Lydia Bennet being the most glaring example of this), I was pleasantly surprised!  Many (including myself) consider the BBC miniseries to be the definitive adaptation of Jane Austen's most popular novel, and as such it is impossible not to compare any newcomers to it.  Happily, this film stands up on its own.  At the beginning of the film, I found myself instinctively comparing the two on a line-by-line basis.  I soon found myself simply enjoying this adaptation.  It is small wonder then that Emma Thompson, whose marvellous adaptation of Sense & Sensibility garnered her a Golden Globe, had a hand in revising this screenplay (though she is uncredited for her efforts).  The script shines with her wit. <br /> <br />The world of the Bennet family is far grittier than the BBC miniseries, the producers of which made a conscious decision to focus on the family in a sort of benign vacuum rather than placing them in the social context of the times.  The resulting reality of the film characters' lifestyle with pigs wandering to and fro in the yard brings the plight of the Bennet girls into sharp focus.  They simply MUST marry well lest they end farmer's wives with no servants and working themselves into early graves.  Or worse yet, poor single women once they are turned out of their home by Mr. Collins, obliged to depend on the kindness of others in Merryton. <br /> <br />The always pleasing Keira Knightley does a lovely job as Elizabeth Bennet.  Rather than portraying her as shockingly pessimistic, she is simply the only member of the Bennet family (save perhaps Mr. Bennet) that does not go through life with blinders on.  Her performance as the conflicted heroine has won her Golden Globe and Oscar nominations, and deservedly so.  Matthew MacFadyen imbues his Darcy with a humanity that makes Colin Firth's Darcy seem wooden in comparison.  Darcy's inward struggle of wills is delicately portrayed with only fleeting glimpses of his utter agony amid the expected reserve of the upper class.  Speaking of wooden, however,  Rosamund Pike's portrayal of the angelic Jane leaves you wanting.  Her \\"reserve\\" as they called it, was a bit overplayed and resulted in a less than sympathetic character.  While Jena Malone does not come remotely close to bringing the bratty self-centeredness of Lydia to her scant screen time.  Had I not been so familiar with the character's innumerable flaws, I might have found myself wondering why she would have been so stupid as to go off on her infamous elopement.  To me, this is the major shortfall of this adaptation.  The elopement is the stomach-sickening climax of the novel, and much of the build-up to Lydia's downfall is omitted as is much of the search for the wayward Lydia.  The result is that the viewer is not as aware of how and why she would do such a thing nor truly the extent of the consequences of her actions.  Brenda Blethyn does an admirable job of portraying Mrs. Bennet as an overbearing, pushy mother without taking on the unbearable shrillness of the miniseries Mrs. Bennet.  Donald Sutherland, though I thought him an unusual choice for Mr. Bennet, is able to convey the guilt and shame that Mr. Bennet carries for not providing adequately for his daughters' futures all the while remaining oddly sympathetic.  Dame Judi Dench was the perfect selection for the imperious Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  However, she is much nastier than the miniseries version - to an uncomfortable extent.  Rather than being simply demeaning in that unconscious way that high-born people of her era were to others below their rank, she resorts to out-and-out cruelty.  Unneccesarily, I might add (though this is a shortfall of the screenplay, not Dame Judi).   <br /> <br />In all, this version of the classic tale is remarkably well done, most especially in the development of the relationship between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.  It is in the interactions of these two characters that the heart and soul of the movie resides; in two people so obviously perfect for each other that neither can see it. <br />

B0006L16N8|5.0|It took me a couple of years to get into Coldplays music, but since hearing Clocks on the radio about 3 years ago, I got hooked on it and today Coldplay is one of my favourite bands.  <br /> <br />These british guys have something to offer. It is not groundbreaking or anything, just plain good poppy rockmusic with a lot of great atmosphere and then also some good messages that makes this world a bit a easier to live in.  <br />Chris Martin has a cool voice that is totally his own (unfortunately other new singers try to copy him) and adds to this somewhat relaxed and at times, dreamy atmosphere that makes up the sound of Coldplay: Reverby guitars, big piano and swirling synthesizers. Beautiful and simple, but effective. <br />Coldplay is to me one of the bands that brings back what I missed in the 90's rockscene, which was very dominated by grunge and so called \\"alternative\\"- bands: Good melodies and lyrics that talks to the average human being and expresses different emotions and moods.  <br /> <br />X&Y became my favourite album in 2005 and actually it still gets better and better everytime I listen to it.  <br />At the first few listens, there were a few songs that I'd skip, namely Square one, Low and Swallowed in the sea. Today I really like these tunes even though they can't compete with my favourites What if, Fix you, Talk, The hardest part, Twisted logic and the untitled last track (Till kingdom come).  <br /> <br />Here are some words about my faves: <br /> <br />What if - A beautiful, heartfelt ballad with meaningful lyrics that makes you think Chris Martin is a guy who thinks about what life and love is worth. This piano and strings-driven song is a true classic to me.  <br /> <br />Fix you - A very big hit in 2005 and a sweet ballad with Mr. Martin singing falsetto through most of the song and being the good friend telling you that he's not gonna let you down when life is just too harsh. I love the way the song builds up from just a slow song with organ, then piano, acoustic guitar and some strings and then delivers a powerful last big chorus with simple, powerful electric guitar and uptempo drums....and then suddenly ends with only Chris Martin and his piano.  <br /> <br />Talk - A great uptempo poprocksong with a big 80es-retro-twist to it, with all the great synthesizers and the hum-along guitarriff taken from Kraftwerks \\"Computerlove\\". I really dig this song! <br /> <br />Speed of sound - A very big hit and a very typical Coldplay-song, if one can speak of such a thing from a band that has only released 3 studio albums. Very piano-driven and reminescent of Clocks because of the chords in the verses, as well as the intriguing drum-rhythm.  <br /> <br />The hardest part - This is a nice radiofriendly song that reminds me a lot of R.E.M because of the sound and the chord-changes. Not much to say about it, except that it's a really good song. <br /> <br />Twisted logic - Haunting lyrics and a strong melody with a slow guitarriff that sounds very much inspired by the last period of the Beatles (1968-1970). Rocky, but still very soft in the verses, while more powerful in the chorus. The strings and chord changes gives this song a very melancholic feel.  <br /> <br />Till kingdom come - A hymn that was originally written for Johnny Cash and sounds totally as if it could have been included in one of his last 3 albums. Chris Martin sings in a very humble manner, only accompanied by acoustic guitar, piano and pump organ. The lyrics are somewhat a prayer to God, carrying hope for reconsilation and resurrection on the day Christ will return.  <br /> <br />What more can I say that hasn't already been said about X&Y at least a 100 times? ;-) If you like modern melodic rockmusic on the softer side, this album is definitely worth every penny. I highly recommend it!!!

0316168815|2.0|I shall review the book with a list of positives and negatives.  Unfortunately, I can name only one positive. <br />POSITIVE <br />The story begins like a murder mystery, albeit told by the victim, Susie Salmon, who is in heaven.  It held my interest almost to the end.  How would the murderer be discovered?  Would the victim, looking down from her heaven, lead the guilty to his judgment? <br />NEGATIVE <br />1)  I read the chapters quickly, expecting a twist or a turn with a plausible ending typical of a good murder mystery.  Only in the last couple of chapters, after much anticipation, does it become apparent that Sebold did not intend the book to read as a mystery.  Her goal, as I see it, was to portray how, after a devastating and horrific event occurs within a family, relationships go awry and the family becomes dysfunctional - a  skeletal form of its once normal body left pathetic with missing parts;  yet somehow, guided by the celestial Susie, there is recovery, and normalcy is regained. And so, the skeletal form is healed - voila, \\"lovely bones.\\"  How misleading!  300 pp of \\"mystery\\" is tossed away as if it never happened! <br />2)  Sebold rambles on excessively and unnecessarily about simple events and thoughts.  Skip some paragraphs and not miss a thing. <br />3)  Sebold's writing lacks originality. <br />    a)  Susie's father's absolute certainty that Mr. Harvey is the killer is based on no real evidence, only on flawed assumptions.  Harvey acts weird, looks weird, never socializes, builds spooky things, looks guilty!  On that basis, I suppose we all could condemn a number of innocent people to the electric chair. <br />    b)  Susie inhabits Ruth's body to make love to Ray.  Is that original?  Absolutely not.  You need only think of the movie, GHOST, which was filmed long before Sebold's book was published.  GHOST stirred favorable emotions within me.  \\"Unchained Melody\\" still rings in my heart.  But this copy-cat scene left me frowning and groaning. <br/>    c)  Sebold devotes chapter after chapter to the misdeeds and sins of the murderer.  Yet, his end, though \\"icy,\\" is abrupt and benign.  No remorse.  No justice served.  Okay, many real-life murderers do get away with it and probably meet a normal death.  But they have no Susies in heaven to watch them and to relate their stories. <br />CONCLUSION <br />The book is easy to read.  It was praised by many and achieved best-seller status for many months.  It is yet another example or proof that popularity of a book does not necessarily equate literary merit.  I read the book for a discussion group.  I suspect my disappointment with the book shall be a minority view. <br /> <br />

0140187650|5.0|Such was the description of Eichmann given by his lawyer, Dr. Servatius. \\"Mailman\\" is quite apropos. What we have in Eichmann is the farthest thing from a dominant personality. He was a joiner and a conformist, but not a man who'd likely be evil outside the historical context of the Third Reich. Honestly, as Arendt's account makes clear, the fellow was a complete non-entity who only felt comfortable when speaking in his native tongue of officialese. As one of the Israeli interrogators pointed out, it is rather inconceivable that such a marginal talent could rise to the level of Lieutenant Colonel in the SS (but look at his peers).<br /><br />A complete psychological study of the man is what Arendt's account achieves, and this is a book to read and read again. Eichmann in Jerusalem is valuable for its journalism, as it covers his trial aptly, but also for its history. As a narrator, Arendt is erudite and clever; although, sometimes she can border on the snide. There are a few things she makes note of which are not entirely accurate as well such as assuming that the July 20th conspirators only turned on Hitler when events went badly in the war. That's not the case. They leaked information to the allies before the war even started. Also, that the Nazis would back down when presented with determined civilian resistance to their anti-Jewish measures is highly dubious. Generally, they always met force with more force, and reprisals were their rule-backing down was the exception. Of course, the information available to Arendt back in 1961 cannot be compared to the tsunami of documentation we have at our fingertips today. Overall, this is a stunning work.

Orchid was a great debut album and I know they do not want to sound like that anymore... they want to progress from that (like any artist strives to do with their work)  I just feel there was a certain intensity in that album that made it be one of my favorites even after the release of their other albums. My Arms Your Hearse captured that same intensity... and this is the intensity I wanted to relive in their latest heavy album.  I have read other reviews on this site... some good and some bad  just to see some constructive critisizm ... it seems the bad reviews I read were very un-intelligent. I have to laugh at someone saying APC is a ripoff of Tool... APC is going to have some likeness because the lead singer is Maynard. Opeth ripping off Tool? I do not even understand that comment... the only similarity to me is that they both have some lengthy songs (which i LIKE) ... Otherwise... the lyrics and sound... are completly different...

B00006L83N|5.0|I've heard people refer to Symphony X as geek metal because of the subject matter (dragons, wizards, medusa, boats).  don't worry,  There's more here than just \\"The Clash of the Titans.\\"  Just so you know, I am a long-term drummer, a short-term guitarist, and a lowsy keyboard player. I've also been forced into the arena of lead and backing vocals at various times.  this is also my first Symphony X album, so this is my viewpoint of the album: <br /> <br />This Russell guy's voice is intense and he really displays his ability to bring about soul and agression to support the mood of the song at any given moment. On top of that, he can read. It seems,according to other reviews, that they get subject material from mythology and literature and write an intense musical soudtrack for us to listen to. These men are atleast classically (lyrically and musically) oriented and not just singing devi, devil, devil for the heck of it.  Most prog metal lyrics out there require interpretation because they are so flowery, vague, and artificially artistic. If you've ever read the Iliad or the Odyssey by Homer and you also like prog metal and aren't ashamed to be numbered with the geeks, get this album. It's a viable alternative to playing Dungeons and Dragons and/or reading Star Wars novels. <br /> <br />The guitar work is very engaging! Especially in the opening tracks. Everyone has an opinion on who's the best, but I think that this guy is better than me so there's alot I can learn from him. I think he's more comparable to Yngwe (however you spell his name...) than petrucci because he's, for the most part, a diatonic and scalar shredder in his solos and more speed oriented in most of his riffs.  If you read the insert in the special edition bonus version they admit that they wanted to focus on the guitar on this album...and it is the most prominent. <br /> <br />The keyboards are very cool, not as prominent as Dream Theater's typical arranging and mixing, but nevertheless, present anadding alot to the songs. I don't know much about the keyboard, but a good one can add a considerable ammount of power to a song.  You'll notice this in the last track especially with the french horns or whichever sound he's emulating...it gives you the sense of hidding a horse with a sword...or sailing in a ship with a canon...intense geek feelings. <br /> <br />Of course the drummer is good.  I love me some doublebass drumming!  He doubles well and complements well. He exhibits nice cymbal work on top of some intense double kick action.  The album picture doesn't show him with this huge siamese monster like portnoy (if that is a virtue to you) but he sounds very polished and complex without all the pots and pans.  I particualrly like the way his snare sounds, it's very well mic'd and cuts through but doesn't over power the mix. <br /> <br />The bass really doesn't stand out in this album, but isn't that always the case? You guys need to star a Bass Player's Tone Union.  I just figure (as with John Myung) that if he can double these riffs, he's good. Most drummers and bass players are underrated anyway. Get used to it. Think of the trade off...along with all the attention, guitarists and singers get 98% of the criticism too. <br /> <br />So wether you are a prog enthusiast, an unemployed musician, a Chronicles of Narnia/Lord of the Rings type geek, or are a connoseur of good 20+ minute songs, direct your mouse to the \\"add to cart\\" button, you won't be disapointed. If you are offended by the album artwork, (look closely at the picture before buying because I didn't) just do what I always do, have your wife open the box first and put happy face stickers over all the naked bodies. <br /> <br />So to all you guys out there that call this album cheese...back off. Some of us like the geek stuff or can overlook it long enough to enjoy some good metal prog neo prog classic baroque prog and roll or what ever the official category is. Think it sounds too much like 80's metal?  Is that really a problem?  Some of us like 80's metal, we don't wear the clothes anymore, but we like the music. You know you want to want to put on your Ratt t-shirt, bang your head (mullet), pump your fist (while wearing a sweat band) and sing along with the over-dubbed Rusells at the end of the title track (The Odyssey)...\\"Triumphant champion of Ithica!\\"  Don't be ashamed, geeks unite!

B00068CVJ4|4.0|It's hard to see how the remnants of At the Drive In turned out. One half turned into a shadowy image of their former selves, Sparta. The other half turned into a pair of dudes who take themselves too seriously, The Mars Volta. Yet, right before all that happened, these guys managed to get out one more creative piece, Relationship of Command.    Many have commented that this one is the best album ATDI has released. That is a rather dubious statement, considering the high quality of their previous efforts. This one happens to be a bit over produced, which is both a good thing and a bad thing.     The production values give the album a more solid punch. It's clear some of these songs benefit from the treatment. On the other hand, it would have been better to concentrate on the actual songs, as the production tends to drown out some of the emotion and energy that ATDI is known for. Still, you can't beat the energy coming from the opening track, Arcarsenal.    The album is well developed, as it does show a maturity that these fellows have obtained. Yet, there in lies their fault: They seem to make everything a little epic on this one. Sometimes, making things simple and straight to the point is better because some things are not meant to be exxagerated. Listen to Invalid Little Department and you will know what I mean.     Overall however, this has to be a solid album. It is very accessible, meaning you will have an easier time to get into this one as opposed to the band's other releases. Chances are if you like this kind of music, you will be very pleased. It does have some amazing songs. But take heed, as ATDI has released albums that better caption their fury. Still, this one is comes highly recommended.
B000DWMYQ8|5.0|We all know the story.  Chicken Little got hit on the head by an acorn, got the whole town into a panic by proclaiming \\"The sky is falling,\\" and then suffered humiliation for his mistake.  Clearly, the little guy is in need of some redemption - and, thanks to the folks at Disney - he finally has it.  He really did get hit on the head by a piece of the sky - actually, a cloaking panel from an alien spaceship.  Redemption doesn't come quickly, however.  A full year after the original embarrassing incident (which never faded into the background, thanks to billboards, a book, and a forthcoming movie about the whole fiasco), it happens to Chicken Little again.  Even with friends to verify the event, no one believes him yet again, not even his father.  It's a terrible thing for a child to tell the truth and have one of his parents not believe him.  The trauma of that feeling, even more than the continuing public embarrassment, has haunted Chicken Little ever since the original incident.  Buck Cluck loves his son, and he tries to be a good single father to him, but he's really not there for Chicken Little in the bad times.  That gulf between an otherwise loving father and son is really the emotional crux of this story, carrying with it a meaningful message to both children and parents alike.<br /><br />Michael Eisner did at least one good thing during his time at Disney - he saw the original image of Chicken Little as a female and changed the minds of the filmmakers on that score.  From that point on, it was smooth sailing - due largely to some wonderful casting for the voice actors.  I think Zach Braff is great as the voice of the little hero, but Joan Cusack and Steve Zahn are pretty much perfect as the voices of Abby \\"Ugly Duckling\\" Mallard and Runt of the Litter, respectively.  With all of their comedic antics, these two characters (along with the amazing Fish Out of Water), really make this a movie that kids are sure to love.  Garry Marshall brings Chicken Little's dad to life, while a whole cadre of talented stars, including Patrick Stewart, Amy Sedaris, and Don Knotts, make even the minor characters delightful.  The only little issue I might have with this film is the music, and I only say that because a good bit of it goes back two or three decades.  When Runt starts doing Bee Gees and Gloria Gaynor songs to keep up his courage, few kids are going to recognize the music - maybe the filmmakers just threw this stuff in as a little extra for adult viewers.<br /><br />As usual, Disney proves quite generous with the extra features on the DVD.  You get the obligatory behind-the-scenes look at the making of the film, three alternate openings and a deleted scene, the music video of Shake Your Tail Feathers by The Cheetah Girls (featuring Chicken Little, Ugly Duckling, and Runt getting down with their bad selves), a music video (not to mention karaoke and sing-a-long versions) of One Little Slip by the Barenaked Ladies, a trivia-related game of \\"Where's Fish?\\" and sneak peeks at gobs of upcoming Disney releases.  The alternate openings are interesting, reflecting the fact that the filmmakers were unsure at first how to introduce the film to the audience, and one of them is quite special indeed, as it features the late Don Knotts narrating the classic tale of the unfortunate little chicken.<br /><br />I'll never be too old to enjoy a good animated film, and the sort of 3D animation that brings Chicken Little's world to life is still quite an amazing thing to see.  At the same time, the animators attempt to retain the essence of the classic Disney style, which ensures that the look of this movie won't be anything less than impressive.  Ye olde squish and stretch never gets old, while the move and zoom point of view technique really goes to show how far animation has come over the decades.  It's that mix of the past and the present that makes this film a real winner in my book.  Chicken Little certainly isn't Disney's most magical film,but it is cute and entertaining enough to delight children as well as a fair share of adults.cal film, but it is cute and entertaining enough to delight children as well as a fair share of adults.

B000002513|5.0|Shouldst thou purchase this CD then you will be making a wise choice. Mr. Springsteen's musical authority is hard to question when such an album is presented. From the E Street Shuffle to Rosalita's overbearing father, the album presents a lifestyle just waiting for change. That change will come with Born to Run but for right now it's just sitting around waiting. It also represents someone's strong desire for that change to come, waiting to leave. It starts with the E Street Shuffle, a song about living in a high-crime area where the cops are constantly after Power and his girl, it would seem, so Power's girl picks him up and they leave. Next on the list is 4th of July, Asbury Park, a song about a guy from the shores of Jersey describing the boardwalk life and why he's done with it and he wants Sandy to let him have her just one time before he's gone. Then we have the jazz influenced Kitty's Back, a good period in the middle of the song is spent mostly on jazzy music but the lyrics, as best I can tell, are about an influential girl who left to go live with some well to do city fellow but got left by him and now she's back. We are now presented a rock and roll (sorta) song called Wild Billy's Circus Story, with a tuba mixed in. It's a slow song about someone who ran away to the circus, in essence. Then it describes the circus life some. Interesting song. Then when that song edges out we are hit by David Sancious' (I think I spelt that right) piano as the next song gears up and becomes Incident on 57th Street, an absolutely beautiful song about two youngin's living in the underworld with the drug racket and gangs and pimps. A Romeo & Juliet  story (Rom and Jul are even mentioned in the song) which does not end tragically but when one's imagination goes past the lyrics we can only think that it does end quite harshly. The girl's father says, \\"He's got no money\\" while Mom says, \\"He's in a rock and roll band\\" as they don't want their daughter to date him. But the singer now has himself a record deal and a \\"big advance!\\" So as far as one can tell the girl hops on the back of his motorcycle (never mentioned, I'm trying to sound smart) and they peel out and go live their life. Lastly we have New York City Serenade. Nothing I type here can give you a true understanding of this song. The piano dominates the two minute + intro with some hard hitting notes but it finally softens up and shows you the easy tune you were being built up for with the guitar joining in. Then Bruce goes to talk about two kids boogalooing down Broadway, a fish lady and vibes man stinging a trashcan. The lyrics make sense when you hear them but if you simply read them you'll think Bruce was on drugs. But it has such a beautiful tune and the lyrics are sung just right that one almost could cry the song is so perfect. A perfect ending to an album.
B000E6UK5K|4.0|I have been a floyd fan for most of my life.  The sublime experiences I have had with their albums over the years have touched my life and, in some dark times, have given voice to my fear and rage and awe and yearning, etc.<br /><br />But, here I am... in the middle of life and I don't feel quite so much fear or quite so much rage.  I'm concerned with companionship and family and kind of looking in front of me and looking in back of me with some apprehension, a little sadness and, dare I write it, gratitude and hope.<br /><br />I have grown so much through and with Floyd.  Why are fans so bothered by what is being termed: adult contemporary musak.  It is still beautifully produced and worked with the woman he loves.  This is about love.<br /><br />No, of course it is not \\"Wish You Were Here\\" or \\"Meddle\\" or \\"The Wall\\".  But then again, nothing every really will be,  including anything the long-suffering Mr. Waters might come up with.<br /><br />I for one am happy for the Gilmores.  I would feel very sorry for Dave and his family if he were still producing that beautiful but pained sort of music.  Angst is for the young.  A sense of well-being and peace is what we all hope to attain.  That is what this album is.  Music for the middle-of-life.<br /><br />BTW, I get uncomfortable when rock-stars refuse to shed their 20-year-old selves.  I mean, really life is about personal growth and evolution.  Dig a little deeper and you might find that this is a fine album, indeed.<br /><br />Lighten up on the guy and his wife.  He really doesn't \\"owe\\" us anything.  As part of Floyd, he's given me more than I can ever thank him for.<br /><br />Thank you, David...
0446577383|2.0|This book has all the requisite thriller ingredients but the result somehow came across as a rote exercise, lacking in inspiration.    The political viewpoints of the author came through too loadly and overwhelmed the plot, which had too many logical flaws to be very believable.  The constant shifts between people and locations made it hard to relate to any of the thinly developed characters and bogged down the story instead of making it more suspenseful.  Finally, the Camel Club itself turned out to be rather incidental to the resolution of the conflict, a let down from the huge buildup it received in early chapters.     Baldacci is too talented of a storyteller to settle for such a mediocre product.  I'd like to see him put more care into his future novels.

B0000025D0|5.0|To truly appreciate this album one must first come to know Born to Run. Born to Run tells us of the romantic dreams of running off into the sunset, chasing whatever hope we have left of our youthful optimism, this is Bruce going major and meeting his dream. But then for almost three years Bruce didn't release any albums. This is because of legal issues and production issues I don't understand but I'll give you that much. It was in this time Bruce also read the Grapes of Wrath; something I don't have any authroity on either. But eitherwho; it led Bruce to realizing that life, even when you make it big time, is still crappy. It starts with Badlands, a deceptive song; the tune is maybe not happy but it's shake-your-fist rock and roll but a tone deaf reading of the lyrics seems to say that being Born to Run down Thunder Road getting away from the boardwalk life of 4th of July Asbury Park leads one to more badlands, that wherever you go things suck. Bruce simply tells us how angry he is that things suck no matter where you go. So the character is basically singing to any girl who'll listen that things are crappy and they're going to be so for a while, lets just take eachother and go make a relationship happen. Adam Raised a Cain is the next song, a song both in lyric and tune that is very angry, a young man rebelling against his father. I won't go too much into it. Next is Something in the Night, lyrically depressing, it sings about that car ride from Thunder Road ending in a way that we didn't expect. Candy's Room comes next, a lustful song about a man who has preconcieved (that's my view of it) notions of being loved by a girl who may or may not be a hooker. I don't know, everybody reads things different. My mom thinks Secret Garden (a few albums down the road from here) is about hookers. Next we have Racing in the Street, a song I truly enjoy about a love soured by time. Then the Promised Land, very upbeat lyric about someone who's in the same crappy world as the guyin Badlands but this guy realizes things will get or at least could get better if he had some control. Factory is a short song about \\"the working, the working, just the working life.\\" Streets of Fire I can't quite get what it's 'about' but it's a good song, simply enough. Prove it All Night is a classic song, mostly a romance song about proving their love to eachother be it through physical actions or superficial items. Darkness on the Edge of Town moodily closes this album basically painting out Born to Run as having limits, that you can only run so far. Yes, a short review, but I'm tired. Long story short is this album is definately worth your money.

B000BW7QWW|4.0|I have to qualify this review with the caveat that I spent a lot of time with the Firefly TV series DVDs before ever viewing this feature. So if you're new to the Firefly universe, I'm not sure how useful my perspective on this film will be to you. From that backdrop, having listened to all the comments from Joss Whedon about what he wanted the show to be, how he adapted it to make it palatable for the network execs, etc., I was not that surprised at the difference in tone from the TV show to the movie. Still, it was a bit jarring at first. The main characters are all a bit darker, a bit colder and harder, than in the TV series. There is an element of warm whimsy in the TV show that is lacking here; or at least it's buried deeper. Of course, it could all be explained by the passage of time and the fact that they've all been cooped up on the ship together for that much longer, and have been having a tough time finding work, etc. At any rate, I felt like I had to make a sort of shift in my perspective, view these characters from a slightly different place, before I could relate to them as the same people I'd grown attached to in the TV show. Once I made that adjustment -- and I really didn't pull it off until the second time viewing the movie -- I found myself in more or less familiar territory. The clever, witty dialog, fine acting with great chemistry between characters, live-action feel with ambient lighting and hand-held camera shots, extending even into the excellent but unobtrusive special effects. One thing I found puzzling was the absence of the western element; as far as I can remember, there was not a single horse in this movie. Puzzling because that was Joss Whedon's original idea for the show -- a Sci-Fi Western. But anyhow, it's a really great story, very well told. I don't think I'll be spoiling anything for anybody if I say that some of the ongoing threads from the TV series will be tied up here. I think the tying-up of the old threads is very artfullyand seamlessly integrated with the present very compelling story, but my perspective may be skewed on that since I'm so steeped in the old threads. Anyhow, not all the old threads are tied up, and that's good news for fans because it means more is coming; let's hope JW finds a way to make it happen.

B0007XAWB2|4.0|The Master and Commander is a book about Captain Jack Aubrey and Doctor Steven Maturin aboard the ship Sophie (a Spanish ship) in the Caribbean, and is part of a huge series of books (20) following the Aubrey/Maturin duo.  While this book may be very popular to some, I found it to be very confusing to someone who is not acquainted with common sea-terms.  The first 150 pages or so are nothing but descriptions of life as a naval officer, but it finally takes off and gets a little more interesting afterwards and become a decent book by the end. <br /> <br /> However, by no means is it a war book.  A few battles happen (I won't say what so as to not ruin the book) but otherwise it is more about life at sea.  The theme that seems to be apparent throughout is that of characters and their interactions with the crew and sea life.  Each main character is very dynamic, and remains to be throughout the story.  Aubrey is a sensible character, but also uses a lot of authority, and Maturin is a timid, intellectual.  The two seem to counter-balance each other frequently throughout the book. <br /> <br /> My biggest complaint with this book however is the amount of typos that are present to even the most casual reader.  They are somewhat frequent and do deter the reader.  Every sentence is well worded however.  Patrick O' Brian's vocabulary is obviously at a high level, and his research and knowledge about life at sea is second to none.  Overall I enjoyed the book; however it could have been a little more interesting in the beginning.  I almost felt like putting the book down before I got through it, and I am glad I did not stop.  I would suggest this book to anyone who enjoys reading about the English Navy, for it is factual, and historically accurate throughout the entire book.  However I would not recommend it to someone (like me) who has (or had in my case) no previous knowledge of basic Naval terms.

B000001G7O|5.0|This is a unique performance of Chaikovsky's  violin concerto. Most professional violinists take the opportunity, when performing this concerto, to demonstrate technical prowess. When listening to most recordings of this piece, you will hear the artist offering certainly very fast tempi in the first and third movements, though in almost every case the tempi in the third can be described as extremely fast. This recording is not one of those. Karajan and Mutter present a fresh interpretation of this piece, and one that adds to the richness and variety of the recorded catalogue. In this performance, rather than the elicitation of dazzling technique (though the technique in the recording is as flawless as live recordings can be), HVK and Mutter seem to strive for the extraction of as much music as possible from the concerto.     If, when listening to music, your enjoyment depends in large part on the extent of pyrotechnics demonstrated, then this is not the best recording for you. But if you find beauty, as I do, in dark and rich tone and color, in smooth and flowing phrases-in essence, the transforming of the violin into the fluid and primal beauty of the human voice-then this is without question a recording you should buy. Here, Mutter does not merely play the concerto on her violin, but instead she \\"sings\\" the concerto through her violin.     Although this recording of the Chaikovsky concerto is likely different from any other you will hear, it is in no way inferior. This is a world class performance in every sense. My ultimate recommendation would be that you buy this recording along with one eliciting more pyrotechnics. Finding one of those won't be difficult-almost every famous violinist you've heard of has made one. If you like Mutter, her second recording of this piece could be a good choice.

0425180638|4.0|Patricia Cornwall seems to be cranking out novels without much thought these days.  I keep reading them, hoping for the best but disappointed each time.  The ridiculous coincidences, implausible plot lines and annoying characters are just plain embarrassing.  What is she thinking?  Nonetheless, though Cornwall isn't at her 5-star best these days, her writing style is still better than most of the bestsellers out there.  I wish Cornwall would go back to the days of crimes committed by unknown perps who have never met much less have an internationally-conspired vendetta against Kay Scarpetta or Benton.  I wish there would be a return to the heart-warming, home-cooked meals with the old interaction between Kay, Lucy and Marino -- this is the element that kept the earlier books so entertaining and made one love the characters.  These days, Lucy highly grates my nerves, and Kay doesn't deserve Marino's friendship.  If you like Patricia Cornwall, you'll love Kathy Reichs.  Her stories are much more realistic, probably because the author is actually a forensic anthropologist.  Her writing style is more clever, too.  Patricia Cornwall's imagery used to be so creative and well-constructed; I loved how she could paint a vivid picture in so few, but perfectly-chosen, words.  Now she seems to ramble on without concern for style whatsoever.  Hypocrit that I am, I read all her books, true;  I keep hoping they'll get better!

0679422714|5.0|My review does not intend to compete with the next few exhaustive reviews. Instead, I intend to capture the essence of the book, which is a fierce exposee of the petty, tyrannical, arbitrary, callous, ruthless and vindictive nature of Chairman Mao. The book is divided in 58 short chapters, each one describing two or three years in Mao's life (usefully referring to his age as well, e.g., 1925-27 * age 31-33).  The strength of the book lies in the extremely documented sources (Russian and Chinese archives and relevant literature were consulted; scores of people were interviewed, such as diplomats, politicians, military personnel, ordinary people). The Bibliography at the end of the book is an impressive 52 pages long, written in small print.  The authors make a convincing case that:  a) Mao was not the benign, enlightened \\"Great Helmsman\\" portrayed by Edgar Snow, Sartre, and the world wide Leftist elites, but a murderous tyrant.  b) Mao did not improve the lot of Chinese people.  c) Mao was a Chinese Stalin.  d) Under his leadership 70 million people died, thanks to his catastrophic policies (e.g., the Great Leap Forward, the Cultural Revolution), purges (the campaigns launched against revisionists, rightists, capitalist roaders), famines and paranoid fear of being deposed.  The authors did a fantastic job in describing the relationships Mao had with his subordinates (Lin Biao, Chou En Lai, Liu Shao Qi) and his wives.   After reading this book do not be surprised if you experience a profound disgust with dictatorial regimes, corrupt human nature and the irrational policies of Communism.   P.S. JUST CURIOUS....What are the reviewers of my review objecting to? No one left a comment, but so far, 76 people did not find my review helpful? What's up with that? Please advise....

B000CPH9I4|5.0|After only being available as an import for several months, The Corrs latest CD \\"Home\\" has finally hit U.S. soil. To be honest, the wait was well worth it (although I bought the UK version when it was released in September of 2005).<br /><br />\\"Home\\" finds the Corr siblings returning to their roots with an excellent collection of traditional Irish songs as well as a few personal favorite pop songs. While there are only two tracks on the album that are in a genuine traditional flavor (Old Hag and Haste to the Wedding), the Corrs trademark Celtic stamp is heard all over this album. Also, for the very first time, the band is heard singing in Gaelic on two tracks.<br /><br />While all four Corrs shine brilliantly here, the spotlight is clearly focused on Andrea Corr whose angelic emotional vocals are at their very best on this album. Her soulful heartfelt rendition of \\"Heart Like A Wheel\\" is a big spine-shivering highlight. Elsewhere violinst Sharon Corr displays dynamic vocal talents with a rare lead vocal on \\"Dimming of the Day\\" (her first lead vocal since \\"No Frontiers\\" on the \\"Unplugged\\" CD).<br /><br />Indeed, all of \\"Home\\" is a geunine treat from Ireland's finest musical family. This is probably The Corrs best album to date and is their strongest and most focused effort. Everything from the music down to the arrangements and vocals are all in place here.<br /><br />This is Irish pop music at its finest, guaranteed.<br /><br />Highly recommended!!!

B00008PX8P|5.0|Between this and the \\"How the west was won\\" CD I've been overloading on Zeppelin lately. I haven't listened to this much Zeppelin since high school. The performances are jaw dropping. They just don't make rock and roll bands like this anymore. Each musician is amazingly talented in their own unique way. One thing about rock bands then as opposed to now (aside from the music being better) is that bands back in the late 60s and 70s had members who were equal as individuals. Each his own character that added that something to the mix. And this is why a band like Zeppelin folded when Bonham tragically died. Could you imagine anyone else filling that drum throne? You don't get that now. Now you hardly know the names of all of the members outside of the singer. I don't think anyone would blink if Fallout Boy's drummer was replaced. Watching the change in the band from 1970 to 1979 is cool also. They look a little more tired by '79 but they still kick ass. You see how Bonham had changed his style to conserve some more energy on stage by the later years due to practicality and not being in the shape he was in when he was 21. In any case for any music fan, this is WELL worth the price. Buy it, you won't be let down.

6304111258|5.0|PUT SIMPLY: \\"The Adventures of Robin Hood\\" really has its act together. Filmed in Color, \\"Robin Hood\\" like \\"Gone With The Wind\\", \\"The Wizard of Oz\\", and \\"Citizen Kane\\", are among the very first truly great modern films. Released in 1938, this was high adventure, and yet was much more than a costume piece with swashbuckling Robin Hood fighting evil, and finding romance. Basically, Robin Hood, a saxon nobleman, lays it all on the line for doing the right thing. To this end, everything about the film, depicts doing the right thing for the right reasons, and in style. What movie theme could possibly beat that!  <br /> <br />ROBIN HOOD IS ALL ABOUT DANGER - FUN & ROMANCE: Robin Hood played by Errol Flynn appears to be a brash rabble-rouser. A rude outlaw without constructive purpose or common decency. In short, lacking any admirable traits beyond his fearless, cocky, boorishness that Maid Marian [Olivia de Havilland] could ever appreciate. Well, that is if such things could be seen as admirable traits.  <br /> <br />Needless to say, Robin Hood wins Maid Marion's heart, and deservedly so, as she comes to know him by his deeds. To this end, the film shows - rather than tells, and in ways that further the plot while maintaining the action, and pace of the film, just like fine literature.  <br /> <br />ROBIN HOOD FIGHTS WORTHY ADVERSARIES AS AN UNDERDOG FOR NOBLE CAUSES!  <br /> <br />Like all great adventures, \\"The adventures of Robin Hood\\", have great personalities playing the roles of heros, side-kicks, but most of all -- VILLIANS! Basil Rathbone, as Sir Guy of Gisbourne, is an able adversary for Robin Hood in all things, and covets the affection of Maid Marion, which Sir Guy's obvious evilness will prevent him from ever attaining.  <br /> <br />The Good King Richard the Lion-Hearted has as his sly nemesis, his own brother, the shrewd and treacherous Prince John. For John, it is England itself, and its plunder that he covets. His brother, the King, is simply in the way, and Richard's absence has made this prospect for John, appear possible. With the ransoming of Richard by Leopold of Austria, the time for the coup was now!  <br /> <br />To this evil end, the two chief villains have henchmen, and sidekicks, the principal being, The Sheriff of Nottingham, played for excellent comic relief by Melville Cooper.  <br /> <br />THE GOOD GUYS ARE THE MERRY-MEN & THE BAD GUYS ARE REAL \\"SOUR-PUSSES\\"!  <br /> <br />Of course, Robin Hood has his merry men. Each of the main three is introduced via a little vignette which illustrates their mettle.  <br /> <br />First - Herbert Mundin, as Much-the-Miller's-son, is the first of Robin's merry men to join up, as he is protected from a death sentence imposed on him by Sir Guy, for poaching, by Robin's physically heroic intervention.  <br /> <br />Second - Alan Hale as Little John, literally runs into Robin when crossing a river on a log. The two do a nice job of joisting, kendo syle, over the river, until Robin falls in after he is bettered. Naturally, the character of Robin is illustrated by his jovial good-sporting nature as he declares, \\"I like a man who can better me\\"! Enter, Little John.  <br /> <br />Third - Eugene Pallette as Friar Tuck. An even more comical confrontation introduces this distinctively stout and coarse voiced character to Robin, and us. Again, Robin ends up in the water, and again, he makes a friend.  <br /> <br />The meetings of Robin with his principal merry-men is from folklore, and well illustrates the basic goodness of Robin, and the company he keeps. This basic \\"merryness\\" is the determining difference between the good-guys and the bad-guys. In this film, the good are merry and bad are real sourpusses!  <br /> <br />----- THE CAST -  <br /> <br />-----*- Errol Flynn - Robin Hood  <br />-----*- Olivia de Havilland - Maid Marian  <br />-----*- Basil Rathbone - Sir Guy of Gisbourne  <br />-----*- Claude Rains - Prince John  <br />-----*- Patric Knowles - Will Scarlett  <br />-----*- Eugene Pallette - Friar Tuck  <br />-----*- Alan Hale - Little John  <br />-----*- Melville Cooper - Sheriff of Nottingham  <br />-----*- Ian Hunter - Richard I the Lionheart  <br />-----*- Una O'Connor - Bess  <br />-----*- Herbert Mundin - Much-the-Miller's-son  <br /> <br />----- ABOUT THE PRODUCTION CREW -  <br /> <br />The production work on this film was absolutely top-notch and reputed to be the rare product of synergy derived from production by committee. The results are a terrific cast and screenplay that the studio converted into a great epic film.  <br />Director William Keighley, who was behind schedule, was replaced during the filming by Michael Curtiz. Curtiz, an astute detail oriented pro, has been credited with the quality of the sets, scenary and costumes. The music score, by Erich Wolfgang Korngold, won the Academy Award as did Carl Jules Weyl for Art Direction.  <br /> <br />     *- Michael Curtiz - Director  <br />     *- William Keighley - Director  <br />     *- Henry Blanke - Producer  <br />     *- Hal B. Wallis - Producer  <br />     *- Seton Miller - Screenwriter  <br />     *- Norman, Reilly Raine - Screenwriter  <br />     *- Walter Scott - Book Author  <br />     *- Tony Gaudio - Cinematographer  <br />     *- Sol Polito - Cinematographer  <br />     *- Leo F. Forbstein - Musical Direction/Supervision  <br />     *- Erich Wolfgang Korngold - Composer (Music Score)  <br />     *- Ralph Dawson - Editor  <br />     *- Carl Jules Weyl - Art Director  <br /> <br />----- MAJOR AWARDS [Wins & Nominations]  <br /> <br />-----*- Best Art Direction (win) Carl Jules Weyl 1938 Academy  <br />-----*- Best Editing (win) Ralph Dawson 1938 Academy  <br />-----*- Best Picture (nom) 1938 Academy  <br />-----*- Best Score (win) Erich Wolfgang Korngold 1938 Academy <br /> <br />  <br />CLOSING THOUGHTS: \\"The Adventures of Robin Hood\\" is a timeless, classic adventure epic whose production values, and attention to detail place it in very select companyamong the best films of any century. B000002J1U|4.0|It seems like everywhere I go people are either saying \\"OMG I LOVE IT!1!!\\" or \\"I used it for skeet.\\" Well, not this review. Nope. I am going to give you a general overall description with being as non-biased as possible.  <br /> <br />-History- <br /> <br />After an exhausting U.S. tour, Zeppelin lead singer Robert Plant and guitarist Jimmy Page went to a cottage in Wales called Bron-Yr-Aur. It had no electricity or running water, and it was here that the two were able to relax. It was also here that much of the material for their third album was going to be written.  <br /> <br />Led Zeppelin III came out in 1970 and was attacked by many critics, and although this had an impact on sales, it still reached number one. While the band's first two albums were a mix of hard rockin' and swingin' blues, Led Zeppelin III combined the elements of blues, rock, and a new element, folk rock.  <br /> <br />-Tracks- <br /> <br />The first track, \\"Immigrant Song\\", is one of the band's most recognizable songs, if not one of the most recognizable songs in rock history. It's sturdy riff and powerful vocals make it easy to remember and sing along to. It may even make you want to get up and dance. It did for me, but that's not saying much. I dance to everything... somehow, someway. Though many people find Plant's Viking-esque screaming somewhat... \\"gross\\", for lack of better words, the guitar makes up for it.  <br /> <br />The second track, \\"Friends\\", is probably my favorite track on the whole album. The first couple of seconds consists of muffled conversation; what these people are talking about I couldn't tell you. The conversation is then replaced with acoustic folk guitar, starting off the actual song with a nice rhythm that you can clap your hands to. Plant joins in with vocals along with orchestrated strings. This adds a nice, though seemingly unnecessary, touch to the song, and it almost adds a nice Eastern style of music to the song. I guess it fits, in someway, since the lyrics remind me vaguely of searching for inner-peace and good karma. Though the bongo-like percussion is rather muffled by the guitar and strings, it's still a rather catchy piece.  <br /> <br />Track three is \\"Celebration Day\\", another well-recognized song. As the title suggests, it's got a party-hardy feel and fast-paced rhythm. The beginning of the track is tied together with the end of \\"Friends\\", which adds a nice touch. In a way, this song reminds me of another Zeppelin hit, \\"The Song Remains the Same\\".  <br /> <br />Track four is \\"Since I've Been Loving You\\", a bluesy-rock song that reaches a nice seven minutes in length. It's very... dramatic, almost, and rather sad. The guitar and vocals fit perfectly, and it's definitely one of those songs you'd wave a lighter to. Another recognizable hit.  <br /> <br />The fifth track, \\"Out on the Tiles\\", is hardly recognizable at all. I had only heard this song once or twice before I bought the album, and that wasn't even on actual radio. However, the beginning guitar chords can be recognized as the introduction used in \\"Black Dog\\" in live albums, such as \\"How the West was Won\\" and \\"BBC Sessions\\".  <br /> <br />\\"Gallows Pole\\" was described by Robert Plant as one of his favorites. It's a folky song about getting ready to be hanged, so it's... morbid? I don't know. It starts off almost mournful sounding, but it picks up the pace with great acoustic work and some nice drumming.  <br /> <br />\\"Tangerine\\", track seven, is another one of those classic love songs. It's very slow, but relaxing. It mostly consists of acoustic guitar, gaining some drum work with the chorus and solo. Plant and his dubbed voice create a nice harmony, and the song was apparently good enough to land itself in a movie.  <br /> <br />Track eight is \\"That's the Way\\", a song that expresses Plant's views of ecology. In other words, it's a hippie/environmentalist song. This song also introduced John Paul Jones' ability to play the mandolin, which adds a nice touch to the acoustic strumming. And, of course, what hippie/environmentalist song isn't complete without the lead singer beating a tambourine at some point? Either way, the song is nice and mellow and lets out a good message.  <br /> <br />Track nine is \\"Bron-Yr-Aur Stomp\\", which was inconveniently mispelled on the album as \\"Bron-Y-Aur Stomp\\". As the title says, it's a song to stomp your feet and clap to. It starts off with a nice acoustic solo and later joins with the \\"stomp\\" made by drums and clapping on every other beat. Plant then sings about his dog, Strider, where he is cut off by another nice solo. The \\"stomp\\" and clapping comes back once again, accompanied with spoons as well. This only adds to the catchiness, which is nothing bad.  <br /> <br />Track number ten was described by critics as \\"pointless noise\\". \\"Hats Off to (Roy) Harper\\" consists of only acoustic guitar and distorted vocals. Had it some kind of percussion, it would've been one of those amazing blues tracks, but alas, it does not. It's still very interesting to listen to, so it all levels out.  <br /> <br />-Conclusion- <br /> <br />Overall, all who like a wide assortment of music (mostly folk) will probably love Led Zeppelin III. I certainly did. It's definitely one of your more mellow rock albums, and it's certainly understandable why it would've been so attacked. Here was a rock band that had been known for its powerful riffs letting out an album that was mostly acoustic. Of course, if you want something that you can still clap your hands to or help you remember the good old days, by all means, buy this album! <br /> <br /> <br />

B000E33VWW|5.0|\\"Capote\\" is the best film I've seen for many, many years. It's thought-provoking to the nth degree and fills in and/or illuminates some of the issues and questions raised by \\"In Cold Blood\\" (while raising and/or murkying others).  I like to come out of a film with my mind racing, and this film did just that.  Seymour is mesmerising. I had to keep reminding myself that he was *not* Truman Capote.  He pulls off - with deceptive ease - the incredibly difficult job of giving a fully-realised portrayal of a man who fashioned his own caricature. It's also wonderful to see that an almost shoe-string budget (by Hollywood standards) can produce such a compelling result. And hardly a CGI in sight!  <br /> <br />A great central performance has to have great support. Chris Cooper as Dewey and Catherine Keener as Harper Lee are superb, as is Mark Pelligrino in the small but effective role of Dick Hickock. The only nigglette I have is about Collins Jr as Perry Smith. Smith must have been particularly difficult to cast; his physical appearance alone would have been hard to replicate.  But Collins Jr's Smith comes across as a misunderstood lad with `issues', rather than the deeply damaged, paranoid schizophrenic of the book. However, the 'ordinariness' of his description of the murders, contrasted with the brutal imagery and sound-track, was just right. Anyway, \\"In Cold Blood\\" itself raises all sorts of issues about the characters and motives of the `real' Smith and Hickock. <br /> <br />This is probably not a film that will be at the top of many people's `must see' list, which is tragic.  It demands attention and rewards concentration. I hope, after the Oscar success, more people will give it the attention is deserves.  <br />

B000B2YQX4|4.0|After listening to this album for several months, I have come to the conclusion that, while overall better than Exciter, it still feels comparatively mediocre for a Depeche Mode release. <br /> <br />The primary problem, in my eyes (or ears, rather) is that the production is just not quite up to the job. DM were clearly trying for a very dark, hard-edged \\"industrial\\" sort of sound with most of the album, and often they just don't seem to push hard enough. The bass synths on songs like \\"John the Revelator\\" and \\"Sinner in Me\\" are trying to be agressive, but still sound relatively tame, and don't have the sort of toothy bite heard on songs like \\"Mercy in You\\" and \\"Rush\\" on Songs of Fath and Devotion. The screeching siren on \\"A Pain That I'm Used To\\" is cliched and feels like a retread of \\"The Dead of Night\\", which was one of the worst songs on Exciter, IMO. <br /> <br />Other times, there are just small oversights and mistakes here and there which prevent the songs from being as powerfull as it could be. Dave's delivery on the words 'console', 'control', 'rules', 'fueled', etc. feels weak, and doesn't have the powerfull baritone quality that his vocals are known for. The same can be said on his delivery of 'in the name of fun' in the song \\"Lillian\\". When working with synth music, the particular sound chosen for a note can be just as important, if not more important than the note or melody it plays, and a few of the sounds here and there on many songs feel poorly chosen. In particular, there is a proliferation of \\"buzzing\\" sounds on songs like \\"Lillian\\" and \\"John the Revelator\\" which are just irritating, don't bring the melody across, and feel like other sounds could have acheived the desired effect better. <br /> <br />Additionally, I'm not sure if Martin's songwriting is quite as good as it used to be. In particular, his ballads (\\"Macro\\", \\"Damaged People\\"), while among the stronger songs on the album, retain some of the over-the-top 'showtune' quality of Exciter's \\"Breathe\\", which keeps them well below the rank of classics like \\"Home\\" or \\"Question of Lust\\". \\"Prescious\\" was nice at first, but feels like a thin and paltry pop single after repeated listens. \\"Prescious\\" was nice at first, but feels like a thin and paltry pop single after repeated listens. It's not a terrible song, but I would not place it among DM's best work by any means. Dave's songs are some of the better ones on the album, and bring a much-needed amount of variety to the mix. <br /> <br />That said, Playing the Angel is not all bad. \\"Suffer Well\\" and \\"Lillian\\" are pretty damn good..not quite on par with \\"Behind the Wheel\\" or \\"Walking in My Shoes\\", but close enough. The beats comes off as a bit generic, but still succeed overall in driving rythim through the song. Dave's and Martin's vocals in these tracks, particularly when harmonized, are powerfull and bring across the heavy sense of angst Depeche Mode is known for. The rest of the songs are not as good, but generally have enough mood to keep you listening through the whole album to get to the better songs. <br /> <br />It's difficult to say deffinitively whether Playing the Angel is truly a better album than Exciter. On one hand, I think Exciter was much more experimental than Angel and suceeded much more in bringing to the listener a sound we had not heard from Depeche Mode before. Particularly for a band which is getting on in it's years, I think it's important to continue to innovate from album to album, and not fall back on retreading old habits. Unfortunately, I think that new sound Exciter brought to the table was just not very enjoyable. \\"Shine\\" and \\"Freelove\\" were great, but the rest of the album was unremarkeable. <br /> <br />Angel is on the whole much more consistent in quality, and much less 'hit or miss' than Exciter. It delivers precisely the fast-paced, empowered hits which were needed as a counter-point to Exciter's mellow ballads. However, nothing on Playing the Angel does anything particularly new with DM's sound... it is largely a rehash of attempted \\"industrial\\" agressiveness which was done by DM with more originality and more subtlety on past albums. I also don't know if \\"Suffer Well\\" and \\"Lillian\\" are quite as good as \\"Shine\\" and \\"Freelove\\", though they are most deffinitely better than \\"Dead of Night\\" or \\"I Feel Loved\\". For these reasons, while Playing the Angel is on the whole much more listenable than Exciter, I am inclined to say that both albums are merely equal, and each only succeeds where the other failed.

B000000Y2R|5.0|Five stars for the music (a no-brainer), but as someone who owns both this Debut/OJC edition and the Spanish import, \\"The Complete Jazz at Massey Hall,\\" on the Jazz Factory label, I must echo the sentiments of \\"shurbuilders\\" (below).  The European edition is from the same company--Disconforme--that did such an excellent job of mastering the \\"Complete Duke Ellington at Fargo Concert,\\" and at an affordable price.  Score them another winner with their edition of the Massey Hall concert.  Not only does the Jazz Factory version contain 24 additional minutes of music, but it has more \\"presence\\" in the treble frequencies (especially noticeable with Roach's drum kit) and features Mingus' original bass lines, which to my ears are sufficiently audible without Mingus meddling with them after the fact.  Moreover, the tunes are complete (the OJC version begins \\"Perdido\\" after the bridge).<br /><br />The strengths of the Spanish import may not be so apparent to listeners who prefer a tighter and shorter program and who have become accustomed to bottom-heavy modern recordings.  Also, the reduced crowd noise on the OJC edition may permit more exclusive concentration on the soloists.  But this was an historic musical event, and no doubt many listeners will wish to experience \\"up-close\\" and in full the magical moment that occurred in Canada on the night of May 15, 1953.  If so, the Spanish import is definitely your best ticket to Toronto.
0393327655|1.0|I do not agree with many writings in the bible.  So, after I was told about this book and read the book reviews in a nearby bookstore, I couldn't wait to read it.  Unfortunately, my reading speed slowed down drastically after Page 2.  On Page 2 of this book, Sam wrote \\"A glance at history, or at the pages of any newspaper, ....... generally have their roots in religion.\\"  This sentence pretty much sets the tone of this book.  Unfortunately, it was not a thoughtful conclusion.  Logically analyzing history record, I found that the root of any war is \\"animal nature\\" or to be more precisely \\"male animal nature\\" which is basically the need of food and female.  For human beings the \\"need\\" developed into \\"greed\\" and \\"heroism\\".  All leaders with much of these personalities know that any \\"difference\\" between two groups can lead to conflict and can be used for them to gather people.  In ancient Asia and Europe, it was always the northern people attacking the southern.  The \\"difference\\" between the north and the south is farmland with sunshine.  In modern days, the \\"difference\\" becomes \\"rich and poor\\", \\"moral and immoral\\", and \\"religions\\".  After a politician tells poor people that he supports ware fare or rich people that he will cut taxes, he will pay a price for his promise after he takes power.  But by emphasizing the \\"difference\\" of morality or religion, the politician doesn't need to do anything for the \\"no cost\\" promise. <br /> <br />So, religion is not the root that divides people.  It is just the cheapest tool, among others, for politicians to gather people to satisfy their greed and heroism.  I'm not sure if Sam tried to use readers' difference on religion to sell his book.  But obviously he is successful in doing so by attributing all evils to religion.  I'll keep on reading this book and provide my opinions by comparing the book with my science training (PhD at Stanford) and personal encounters with people who allow them to be possessed by spirits.     <br /> <br />
0060931736|5.0|This is an easy to read classic story by an author who puts the spark into sparkling.<br /><br />Enter the world of Miss Jean Brodie in her prime, a teacher in 1930s Scotland, she is a woman on a mission, to put \\"old heads on young shoulders,\\" and she sets out to do this with a group of girls who become known as the Brodie Set.  Miss Jean Brodie has her enemies in the school she works in because she is considered too \\"progressive\\" but she is too shrewd to get caught and she relies on the loyalty of her set to keep silent about what they know about her life, politics and beliefs.<br /><br />Miss Jean Brodie is certainly no ordinary teacher; she admires Mussolini, and can't see anything wrong in Hitler's socialism, and she sees no harm in telling her \\"gels\\" about the young lover she had who died on Flanders Fields in the First World War.  She is also incredibly manipulative, she is in love with Teddy Lloyd the Art teacher but she has to take the moral ground and deny herself this passion, instead she grooms one of her girls to become Teddy's lover, wanting to live vicariously through this girl who will through another of the girl's tell her how the affair is going on.<br /><br />The story jumps between the past and present with ease, one minute you are with the Brodie set when they are juniors, the next you are with them when they are 18 and then you briefly see them as adults when they are scattered to the wind and living individual lives.<br /><br />One of the central characters is Sandy, who is the first to realise that Miss Jean Brodie is dangerous, her ideals and beliefs can get people killed, and that she has to be stopped at all costs.<br /><br />Miss Brodie spends the rest of her life trying to find out which of her \\"gels\\" betrayed her and near the end of her life realises that it is the one girl she did not think it could be, Sandy, now a nun and famous for a book she has written called the \\"The Transfiguration of the Commonplace.\\"<br /><br />This is a witty, sparkling, darkly humoured novel about relationships and what makes them tick.<br /><br />A delicious book that has been made into a splendid film with Maggie Smith, it doesn't completely follow the novel but all the same Maggie Smith is superb as Miss Jean Brodie.s is a witty, sparkling, darkly humoured novel about relationships and what makes them tick. <br /> <br />A delicious book that has been made into a splendid film with Maggie Smith, it doesn't completely follow the novel but all the same Maggie Smith is superb as Miss Jean Brodie.

B00068ULLY|5.0|Once upon a time in El Paso, Texas a wedding party is slaughtered execution style. However, it turns out that the Bride (Uma Thurman), who is pregnant, is not dead but in a coma. Four years later she wakes up, no longer pregnant, in time to save herself from insult being added to her injury.  Then the Bride puts together her list of people to kill: (1) Vernita Green (Vivica A. Fox), (2) O-Ren Ishii (Lucy Liu), (3) Budd (Michael Madsen), (4) Elle Driver (Daryl Hannah), and (5) Bill (David Carradine).  In \\"Kill Bill, Volume 1,\\" the Bride only gets to the first two names on her list, albeit not in that order the way the film is cut, and then proceeds to the rest in Volume 2.  This does not constitute a spoiler because you cannot have a film called \\"Kill Bill\\" that does at least get to the title character, regardless of the results.  But then this was a do-it-yourself \\"Box Set\\" (I bought the two DVDs and they gave me a box to put together).<br /><br />There is more happening in the each film besides the kill list, such as an anime telling us how O-Ren Ishii became the Queen of the Tokyo underworld and the training sequence in which the Bride studies with the great Pai Mei.  But in the first film the primary emphasis is on how the Bride takes out her first two victims and the triumph of style as substance, especially when style means fountains of blood gushing from human beings that would make Akira Kurosawa proud.  With \\"Pulp Fiction\\" Tarantino made his impression upon our ears with scene after scene of great dialogue. No wonder the soundtrack for that film had clips of some of what came rolling off the tongues of the actors (usually Samuel L. Jackson, who only plays a corpse in these films). But with \\"Kill Bill, Volume 1\\" Tarantino's blood feast is mostly for the eyes. This film is not for everybody, but then what Quentin Tarantino film ever was?<br /><br />The biggest complain about Volume 1 is that it has the two most memorable sequences in the entire epic, namely watching O-Ren Ishii and her posse walk glide into the House of Blue Leaves with the blasting soundtrack giving them energy and the final showdown in an exquisite garden at night with gently falling snow where O-Ren in her white kimono and the Bride in her yellow biker suit do their dance of death with Japanese steel.  Nothing in Volume 2 tops either of those scenes, which is not necessarily a bad thing, just a cinematic reality.<br /><br />The caveat when Mirimax decided to split this four-hour revenge film into two volumes was that those who sensed a lack of character development and motivation in Volume 1 would be appeased by what was put forth in Volume 2, and this is indeed the case. We finally get to go back and see a couple of pivotal scenes set before the \\"beginning\\" of the film's opening, such as the massacre at the Two Pines wedding chapel. The net result is that character is more important than killing in the last half of the film, which makes sense because it would really be virtually impossible for the Bride to slice and dice more opponents than she did at the House of Blue Leaves.<br /><br />I watched Volume 1 on DVD again before I went to see Volume 2 in the theater, which I thought would put me perfectly in the narrative flow.  However, Quentin Tarantino has set up his audience just to play with their minds, which, of course, is what he was doing from the start and at the climax of this film I was not at all sure who, if anyone, was going to come out alive.  Certainly what happens with numbers 3 and 4 are not what you expected after seeing the fate of numbers 1 and 2, but that certainly puts what happens with the final name on the list up for grabs.<br /><br />There are a lot of oppositions between the two halves of this film. The beautiful setting of the duel between the Bride and O-ren in the gentle falling snow is countered by the showdown with Budd (Michael Madsen) in the harsh sunlight of his trailer in the desert. Having devoted an entire chapterto Hattori Hanzo creating his most perfect sword for the Bride, it is amazing how hard it is to get the sword out of its scabbard in this one. Volume 1 was a feast for the eyes, but in Volume 2 Tarantino's dialogue becomes more prominent, although not quite up to the level of \\"Pulp Fiction.\\" But the dialogue is important because before we get around to the titular business of this film, the Bride and Bill have got to have themselves a conversation. Sound also matters more in this film: there is one sequence that is effectively done in the dark.<br /><br />I am barely acquainted with the genre of Hong Kong films that Tarantino was apparently weaned on, so everything is fairly new to me and consequently smacks more of homage than parody, which is no doubt the director's intent. I probably will not go out and check out some of the films that inspired Tarantino to do \\"Kill Bill\\" which have been pointed out to me, because they will undoubtedly pale in comparison to the slicked up version that he is serving for our American palates. All things considered, I have a definite preference for Volume 1, which seems to run counter to the prevailing sentiments, but it took me a while to be comfortable with how the two parts fit together.  The key thing is that they do, without Volume 2 being simply more of the same, because it is definitely not. There is something to be said for Tarantino pulling out all the stops just to have fun.entire chapter to Hattori Hanzo creating his most perfect sword for the Bride, it is amazing how hard it is to get the sword out of its scabbard in this one. Volume 1 was a feast for the eyes, but in Volume 2 Tarantino's dialogue becomes more prominent, although not quite up to the level of \\"Pulp Fiction.\\" But the dialogue is important because before we get around to the titular business of this film, the Bride and Bill have got to have themselves a conversation. Sound also matters more in this film: there is one sequence that is effectively done in the dark.  <br /> <br />I am barely acquainted with the genre of Hong Kong films that Tarantino was apparently weaned on, so everything is fairly new to me and consequently smacks more of homage than parody, which is no doubt the director's intent. I probably will not go out and check out some of the films that inspired Tarantino to do \\"Kill Bill\\" which have been pointed out to me, because they will undoubtedly pale in comparison to the slicked up version that he is serving for our American palates. All things considered, I have a definite preference for Volume 1, which seems to run counter to the prevailing sentiments, but it took me a while to be comfortable with how the two parts fit together.
